natural problem: Find $a$ if the remainder is constant when $10x^3-7x^2+ax+6$ is divided by $2x^2-3x+1$.
natural solution: We perform the polynomial division: \[ \begin{array}{c|cc cc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{5x} & +4 \\ \cline{2-5} 2x^2-3x+1 & 10x^3&-7x^2&+ax&+6   \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{-10x^3} & +15x^2 & -5x \\ \cline{2-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 8x^2 & (a-5)x & 6 \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & -8x^2 & +12x & -4 \\ \cline{3-5} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 & (a-5+12)x & 2 \\ \end{array} \]The remainder will be constant if and only if $a-5+12=0.$ So $a = \boxed{-7}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x a :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 10 * x powr 3 - 7 * x powr 2 + a * x + 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x powr 2 - 3 * x + 1"
and h2 : "\<exists> r. \<forall> x. P x = Q x * (\<lambda> x. x) x + r"
shows  "a = -7"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find $a$ if the remainder is constant when $10x^3-7x^2+ax+6$ is divided by $2x^2-3x+1$. The final Answer is -7
 ### Proof
 We perform the polynomial division: \[ \begin{array}{c|cc cc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{5x} & +4 \\ \cline{2-5} 2x^2-3x+1 & 10x^3&-7x^2&+ax&+6   \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{-10x^3} & +15x^2 & -5x \\ \cline{2-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 8x^2 & (a-5)x & 6 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & -8x^2 & +12x & -4 \\ \cline{3-5} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 & (a-5+12)x & 2 \\ \end{array} \]The remainder will be constant if and only if $a-5+12=0.$ So $a = \boxed{-7}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x a :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 10 * x powr 3 - 7 * x powr 2 + a * x + 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x powr 2 - 3 * x + 1"
and h2 : "\<exists> r. \<forall> x. P x = Q x * (\<lambda> x. x) x + r"
shows  "a = -7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the value of $a$ in the equation $P(x) = 10x^3 - 7x^2 + ax + 6$ such that it can be expressed as $P(x) = Q(x)x + r$, where $Q(x) = 2x^2 - 3x + 1$ for some constant $r$. The final answer is $a = -7$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 10 * x powr 3 - 7 * x powr 2 + a * x + 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x powr 2 - 3 * x + 1"
and h2 : "P x mod Q x = const"
shows  "a = -7"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find $a$ if the remainder is constant when $10x^3-7x^2+ax+6$ is divided by $2x^2-3x+1$. The final Answer is -7
 ### Proof
 We perform the polynomial division: \[ \begin{array}{c|cc cc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{5x} & +4 \\ \cline{2-5} 2x^2-3x+1 & 10x^3&-7x^2&+ax&+6   \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{-10x^3} & +15x^2 & -5x \\ \cline{2-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 8x^2 & (a-5)x & 6 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & -8x^2 & +12x & -4 \\ \cline{3-5} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 & (a-5+12)x & 2 \\ \end{array} \]The remainder will be constant if and only if $a-5+12=0.$ So $a = \boxed{-7}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 10 * x powr 3 - 7 * x powr 2 + a * x + 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x powr 2 - 3 * x + 1"
and h2 : "P x mod Q x = const"
shows  "a = -7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: For all real numbers x, let P(x) = 10x³ - 7x² + ax + 6 and Q(x) = 2x² - 3x + 1. If the remainder when P(x) is divided by Q(x) is a constant, find the value of a. The final answer is -7.

a_2.formal problem:

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 10 * (x powr 3) - 7 * (x powr 2) + a * x + 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * (x powr 2) - 3 * x + 1"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
shows  "a = -7"

 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & -8x^2 & +12x & -4 \\ \cline{3-5} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 & (a-5+12)x & 2 \\ \end{array} \]The remainder will be constant if and only if $a-5+12=0.$ So $a = \boxed{-7}.$
 *)

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 10 * x powr 3 - 7 * x powr 2 + a * x + 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x powr 2 - 3 * x + 1"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + c"
shows  "a = -7"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find $a$ if the remainder is constant when $10x^3-7x^2+ax+6$ is divided by $2x^2-3x+1$. The final Answer is -7
 ### Proof

 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & -8x^2 & +12x & -4 \\ \cline{3-5} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 & (a-5+12)x & 2 \\ \end{array} \]The remainder will be constant if and only if $a-5+12=0.$ So $a = \boxed{-7}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 10 * x powr 3 - 7 * x powr 2 + a * x + 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x powr 2 - 3 * x + 1"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + c"
shows  "a = -7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given that $P(x) = 10x^3 - 7x^2 + ax + 6$ and $Q(x) = 2x^2 - 3x + 1$, such that $P(x)$ is a divisor of $Q(x)$ and $P(x)$ equals to the product of $Q(x)$ and $R(x)$ plus some constant $c$. What is the value of $a$? The final answer is $a = -7$.

theorem
fixes x a :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 10 * x powr 3 - 7 * x powr 2 + a * x + 6"
